bio.p: Philip Hubbard (PhD, University of California, San Diego) is Senior Lecturer in Linguistics and Director of English for Foreign Students in the Stanford University Language Center. He has been active in computer-assisted language learning (CALL) for nearly 30 years and published on CALL theory, research, methodology, courseware development and evaluation, teacher education, learner training, standards, and listening. He is an associate editor of Language Learning & Technology and Computer Assisted Language Learning and an editorial board member of the CALICO Journal, ReCALL, and Writing & Pedagogy. He has also served twice on the CALICO Executive Board.

Mathias Schulze (PhD, UMIST) is Associate Professor of German and director of the Waterloo Centre for German Studies at the University of Waterloo in Canada. He co-edits the CALICO Journal and is conducting research on Intelligent CALL, online language learning, the development of language proficiency, and also on phenomena of societal bilingualism.

Bryan Smith (PhD, University of Arizona) is Associate Professor of English at Arizona State University's Tempe campus. His research focuses on computer-assisted language learning (CALL)—specifically, the intersection of CALL and SLA. He is co-editor of the CALICO Journal.
